Example

Find \(x\) if \(10^x-5+6(10^{-x})=0\).

Solution

We first simplify this expression by multiplying through by \(10^x\) (to eliminate the term \(10^{-x}\)): \[10^x(10^x)-10^x(5)+10^x(6(10^{-x}))=0,\] or \[(10^{x})^2-5(10^x)+6=0\qquad\text{since}\qquad 10^x(10^{-x})=10^0=1.\]

We realise that this expression is a quadratic equation. Let us put \(y=10^x\) to give \[y^2-5y+6=0.\]

Now, we can factorise to give \[(y-3)(y-2)=0 \qquad \text{so that}\qquad y=3\quad\text{or}\quad y=2.\]

For each of these values of \(y\) we obtain a separate value for \(x\) since \(y=10^x\).


Case 1 If \(y=3\) then \(3=10^x\) implying \(x=\log_{10} 3=0.4771212\).


Case 2 If \(y=2\) then \(2=10^x\) implying \(x=\log_{10} 2=0.3010300\).


We conclude that the equation \(10^x-5+6(10^{-x})=0\) has two possible solutions for \(x\): either \(x=\log_{10} 3\) or \(x=\log_{10} 2\).
